description:
This scary unsolved mystery looks at Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon, two girls who disappeared in Panama's jungle. Police found over 100 photos from their camera revealing their final moments, but still no one can explain what happened.

On April 1st, 2014, Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon disappeared in the jungle of Panama. Despite several search operations, they remained missing for several weeks. It wasn't long before locals began to stumble on strange clues in the area where they vanished, including a camera containing hundreds of disturbing photos that can't be explained, and their mobile phones. Today I review the photos and data left behind, as well as show a newly leaked image. Was this an accident, or something more? Share your thoughts below.

comments.text: Tourists don't realize that these remote places can be very dangerous. I live in central america and I never walk in the jungle alone or without a gun or a machete with me. People need to be better educated before strolling into countries and just going wherever they feel like.

As we were driving on a dark road when we came across around 20 Panamanian military soldiers on maneuvers. They wanted us to step out of our vehicle. They were putting their hands on us and honestly the only thing that saved us was a woman officer that came up and told them to back off. comments.text: According to the mother of one of the locals that met Lisanne and Kris, they were murdered by a local gang that included the son of the Tourist Guide. They did not disappeared hiking El Pianista, they were seen in the town later that day. There's a photo that shows the girls swimming with some local boys in a hot spring, there are several versions about what happened, but it seems that the girls were partying with the gang and the son of the tourist guide wanted Kris to have sex with him, she rejected him and he killed her with a hammer. Lisanne tried to help her only to be murdered too...their bodies were dismembered and burried. When the families offered the reward, the culprits decided to handle the backpack and also claimed that some bones of the girls were accidentally found, however the families decided not to make the payment and instead they donated the money to build a school. The weird photos were taken by the murderers in order to create a story that made the whole thing pass as an accident and the authorities of Panama and the Netherlands took the bait.

comments.text: Throughout my career Iâ€™ve worked with agency guys who conducted ops in several South American jungles. Itâ€™s not the animals or local tribes people you have to watch out for. You also have to contend with military and para military groups, several different police agencies and as a foreigner you have no idea whoâ€™s team theyâ€™re playing for. My opinion is they came across bad people or a camp of bad people doing one of the above mentioned acts and found themselves in a world of trouble. Never go to a third world jungle without 1. A local trustworthy guide 2. Armed to the teeth as most officials are when they go in. Most people who live in relatively peaceful countries have  to realize that the world is not sunshine and bubbles and ALOT of countries can be a tough and dangerous place to navigate especially with a touristy gullible mentality.

comments.text: I've followed this case for a long time. I've watched probably 20 videos on YouTube about it. Not one of those videos has told us if the bottle of water found in the bag was full or empty. If it was full, then how could two girls survive for eight days without drinking that water? Impossible. It's a tiny bottle so they decided to 'save it' for later?  I can't see that. If it was empty, who would think about packing an empty bottle away in a bag, if you're supposed to be stressed out and 'lost', or maybe injured. Another thing that bothers me is the bras also found in the bag. Were they the same bras the girls were wearing when they ventured out that day? If so why would they take their bras off and pack them nicely in the bag. Also, if they were spare bras. What woman would pack a spare bra for a short walk? You'd be better off packing more water right? None of these things have ever been questioned. Packing stuff in a backpack has to mean the girls were murdered.  Packed by someone else. Unused water? The bras they were wearing? Come on, guys, talk about this!!

comments.text: Is anyone else filled with a kind of deep sadness after hearing about this case? I've been thinking about it and returning to it for a week now and I just can't get it out of my head. My first thoughts to explain how I feel is that it's a 'morbid curiosity'... like the gruesome car-crash you just can't look away from which will end up giving you nightmares. There may be a little of that, but in my mind it is so much more. I actually feel major empathy for these two young girls, especially after reading their diaries and hearing other people describe them. It really is beginning to feel like they were people that I knew personally and it's breaking my heart the more I think of it. I've looked at many gruesome things online and read many stories, but none have affected me the same way. (though the case of Karlie Guse also came close). The photos of these girls last trip didn't feature anything gruesome, but looking at their smiling faces knowing what is about to happen is probably one of the creepiest, scariest and saddest thing I have ever seen... especially once day turns to night and we see all those photos probably taken by a panicked Lisanne which may have just witnessed her best friends death moments ago. Looking at all those call logs to 911/112 as they go from being calm to desperation to hopelessness until finally the phone opens one more time before it shuts off forever. Goodbye Kris and Lisanne. I'm going to have a drink and listen to Lyyke Li- I follow Rivers. I'm sorry that the river you were following didn't lead you two to safety </3

comments.text: Sounds like Panamanian police wanted to just close the case because it was getting a lot of airplay. No way this was an accident and no animal killed them. Even IF it was to be argued as they got lost and died; why would a lost individual walk to a rice paddy, a sign of civilization, drop their bag with vital items and walk back into the jungle? If it was an animal, why would a jaguar drag a kill across a jungle for hours? Big cats like leopards or jaguars take kills into trees, not hours across the terrain for other predators to steal. Dumped items, dismembered body parts, pictures erased with forensic precision in the middle of a jungle; So many things point to homicide that a child could figure it out. So saddening to see these women not get justice for the loss of their lives by another person. Very common it seems unfortunately.

comments.text:
There's also the "swimming photo", where Kris and Lisanne are apparently in the water with two local guys...who also died mysteriously, one of them just a few days after the girls went missing. Nobody seems to know exactly when that photo was taken, and the girls didn't mention the swimming excursion in their diaries. There was a rumor that the photo was taken on April 1st -- that they DID come back from their hike, went swimming, and then met with foul play, which would explain some of the things found in the backpack. But it doesn't explain the night photos and emergency calls. In other words, I'm as puzzled by the case as I was when I started looking into it about a month and a half ago. 
It seems like whenever you settle on a possible theory as to what happened, there are a bunch of other facts that contradict it.

comments.text: At some point, Kris likely passed after a sustained injury, and Lisanne didn't realize, thinking (hoping) she was unconscious. Lisanne probably attended to Kris' wounds with whatever was available, fruitlessly.  She carried Kris with her, but the slow and deliberate movements she had to make in such an effort likely attracted attention, either from gangs or wildlife. The night photos might be an attempt to frighten away or identify pursuers, a last-ditch effort made on low battery, and might not have needed a PIN (I know my phone has an emergency camera feature that does not require unlock). Many of the decisions made are hard to explain, but reason is often subdued by the franticness of emergency. May these two souls rest in peace, and the families they left behind find closure.
comments.author: @anecnhoj572

May their souls rest in peace.

comments.text:
I recently subscribed to your channel and didn't expect to see you cover a case from my own country, this one in particular I remember making national news back when it happened, you honestly covered it way better and in more detail than the news did back then. I find this case to be very intriguing the thing is I do believe there was foul play involved but was it from the very beginning? Was it 10 days after? Anyways I'd like to add that I think it's highly unlikely that it was gang violence, or at least local gangs from chiriqui. I lived in chiriqui for some time so I know the area, gangs there usually operate within their own neighborhood violence is concetrated mostly to the city of David(note I say city but it's more of a big town) and the city is actually quite far from where this took place. That aside, if you check a map you'll notice that the region borders with costa rica and it is known that drug smugglers operate around the area so I find the possibility of the girls coming across drug smugglers much more likely, lost in the jungle and starving they might have had little choice but to follow along. 2nd theory I have is that probably some from the indigenous Ngabe tribe did it, among them rape and abuse is not an uncommon ocurrence, you see many of them often live in isolated areas for their entire lives and tend to have little contact with the world outside, I knew of a case of one disabled girl that got raped by multiple people and then got pregnant, another case about a guy that got gangraped by 10 men and then went crying to his dad and his dad casually scolded him telling him that it was his own fault that this had happened AGAIN because he should know better than to get drunk with others.(because it was the 2nd time it happened apparently) because of the circumstances sorrouding these cases(remote areas, language barrier, illiterate people and just having their own different culture) many of these cases don't even get reported to the police and the few that actually do, are pretty hard to investigate due to how remote some of the areas are. 

Ps: for anyone who thinks about coming to panama and having and adventure in the jungle don't even think about doing so without a guide, heck I'm a local and steer clear, cause those 2 weren't the first to die in the jungle and most certainly won't be the last either.
comments.author: @milesedgeworth6353

comments.text: Here in Panama you dont go to the jungle alone like this case, all the natural parks and jungle areas are riddled with shipping and receiving points of drug traffic and others things that a normal panamanian would not imagine, only the last year 7 teenagers were killed in a jungle area in Colon province.
comments.author: @elwacho9910

comments.text:
Strange coincidences and things that don't add up:

1. The dog returned back to the host family, but the girls did not obviously. The dog probably KNEW the attacker, as they were a local.
2. The girl's items and clothes, everything had been went through and rummaged around, as if someone was looking for something.
3. They were suppose to go with a GUIDE, but decided to go by themselves on the hike. They got a bad vibe from the dude.
4. The backpack was found several kilometers away from where the bleached bones were found.
5. The camera might have been used to illuminate the dark, after they got lost, but someone found it and deleted 1 photo in particular.
6. The phone logs indicate someone tried to use a PIN code to access it, but couldn't, so they powered off the device.

It's pretty clear what happened here. These poor girls were killed and kept captive. I think someone showed up on the trail and offered to take them on a shortcut back to the village, but then dismembered and killed them, taking their bra and backpack to plant the evidence in the rice patties. That is why the contents weren't wet or dirty from the river. So freaking sad. I believe Kris was held as a hostage and the picture of her hair was after she was dead, to try and throw the police off. EDIT: Getting a lot of comments around the "Bleached bones" aspect of the case. In very short summary the bleaching exhibited was proven to not be possible from the sun as the bones contained phsophorus not found in any significant abundance in any soils in the region. This is also usually present from chemical bleaching. It seems the bleaching was artificial for this and many other reasons. Article here, scroll a quarter way down to the blue title "The Effect Of Sunshine On Bones" - https://imperfectplan.com/2020/07/02/kris-kremers-lisanne-froon-panama-bleached-bones/

I know it's a well covered case but I felt like a lot of analysis behind this case had always been glossed over... the mobile and camera data just does not add up. comments.text: There is absolutely no way that the girls got lost on the Pianista trail.  Photo 509 is the key as it most likely reveals the people responsible for their disappearance, that is obviously why it was erased at a later date with a computer.  The emergency calls after the 1st day and the night time photos are subterfuge.  The emergency calls on the 1st day, April 1, are most likely from the girls, but all after that day are not from them.  For argument's sake, let's say that the girls kept walking past the Mirador on the other side of the continental divide past the small waterfall in photo 508.  If the 1st emergency phone call was at 4:39 PM and the girls reached the Mirador at roughly 1:00 PM, then they would still be walking on the trails for over three hours before the 1st emergency call.  Let's say that they did eventually get lost, then why aren't there any photos of them on the trail after 508? They wouldn't have gotten lost right away, so they would still be walking and enjoying themselves and taking photos.  If you believe in the sequential order of the photos, then they obviously ran into some people right after 508 and 509 is most likely a photo of those people.   They then led them down another path never to be seen again.  If the sequence of the photos was changed, then they most likely returned to the base of the trail and were then intercepted by some guys who convinced them to take a ride with them.  Either way the girls never got lost on the trail.

comments.text:
I recently watched a video of Kris Kremer's parents following the trail of their daughter's footsteps and from their last supposed camera shots, and for some strange reason I get a very uncomfortable feeling when I watch Feliciano on screen here, his body language is very quick to react and eye contact very tense...
I dunno but maybe its because I followed this case and all theories very closely, and this guys face creeps me out trying to imagine the possibility of these girls stalked by this man and possibly accomplices deep in the jungle and probably hiding out for their lives.

I don't think they intentionally led off from the trail - I believe they ran into trouble and were followed so therefore they went another direction, perhaps out of their own fear or by force.

Of course we will never truly know - its too late with that due to the poor handling of the investigation and (in in my opinion) the coverup from Panama due to it's commercial tourist factor being affected.

However I'm aware this is only speculation and I believe we can only go by hardcore evidence.
But there's no denying that Feliciano is tied to a lot of areas of the case, in terms of the said appointment to guide them, searching their apartment rooms for over 30 minutes to an hour after them being missing without any authority present, and also the remains being very near the farm Feliciano resided on.

I want to believe this was just a tragic accident (based on all theories presented) due to being lost, but when you go down that trail of logic it gets very strange. 

Either way, its tragic these two beautiful and promising young women had such a terrible end, and there's no denying it must have been terrifying no matter what the cause of death was.

RIP Kris & Lisanne.

Tourists from America, Canada, Australia and other western countries who travel to tropical nations sometimes grossly miscalculate the environmental hazards that are eminent in such areas. comments.text: I've been watching several vids about the topic. Personally I think it went like this: they wanted to go to swim in the nearby waterfall, which they found out about online when looking for things to do in boring little village while waiting for their volunteering work to start. They packed light back bag for swimming: little bit water, some cash and bikinis. After all, they were planning to hike a bit, have a swim and come back in the evening. They hiked the trail to the top of the mountain and then tried to find to the waterfall nearby. They left the path confidently and descended, but couldn't return back to the trail because it was too steep or one of them got injured while descending the mountain. They tried to call emergency services for help. Call didn't get through. Sun was setting and they panicked. They tried to go around to the mountain to get back to track quickly, but lost the sense of direction. They tried to scream for help, the locals didn't want to get involved as they thought someone was being murdered and didn't want to get into trouble themselves. Night photos were either an attempt to gather attention of the rescue helicopter which they heard or a predator like big cat was pursuing them and they tried to scare it away. So they used the flash of the camera for this. As for the backbag. I think some local found the bag and picked it up. They tried to open the phone so they could use it, but they didn't guess the right PIN code. After the whole situation escalated, they must have heard about the incident on the news. Being scared of probability of being accused of murder, the local returned their possessions to be found. They didn't want to incriminate themselves, so they took it far from their dwellings. Maybe eventually the big cat caught them. Being exhausted, dehydrated and confused they were easy pray. I think they stopped taking photos to conserve the battery if they needed. If they were scared and confused, I don't think the first thing they want to do is take selfies. I've gotten myself lost in a jungle and it's very scary how fast the sun sets in jungle. You can almost see the sun going down. Panic hits pretty fast when you realise you have only 10 to 15 mins before it's completely black.

comments.text:
It's very easy to get lost in forests if one has little knowledge and little experience of them, and similarly easy to come to grief.  I suspect that  this is what happened and that there was no foul play involved (unless the imcompetence of the Panamanian authorities can be described thus). Neither of these very young women had much experience of the world outside their little corner of Europe, and in particular of the hot, humid jungles of Central America; that is obvious to those who do. Despite or because of that they decided not only to not t ake a guide but to go off the path into an area even the local indigenes avoid at that time of year. They got lost and Kris fell from a height, breaking her femur. Lisanne, the more athletic of the two, clambered down to help her, perhaps injuring hereself in the process, but Kris was unable to move so Lisanne stayed with her..They remained in that place trying to phone emergency services, but gradually their health deteriorated because of lack of  food, lack of sleep and perhaps dysentry due to drinking contaminated water from the river. Kris died first. Lisanne hung on for a while, her health both physical and mental declining even further. One night, perhaps, in a last desperate bid for help, she used the flash on her  camera to signal helicopters she could hear, or to scare off a jaguar ( which animals have been reintroduced in that area by the Panamanian authorities) or puma, drawn to the scent of blood or near death rather as vultures are. Shortly afterwards she died too.
Not long after that the weather changed and it rained heavily. The rivers rose and their bodies were carried off-perhaps already only in part because   the predators had not been scared off. Whatever else there was got carried far and wide by the waters , decomposing with the help of various creatures and substances as well as the weather conditions.
The bag had been at the place where they stayed but perhaps a little higher up and sheltered. It remained where it was until some time later when someone found it. Probably ignoring the bras therein which the young women had taken off due to their being irksome in the humid heat, and  focusing on the passport which would sell for three thousand dollars, and the gadgets which would sell for a good sum, he took it back to his home. Then he found out though that it belonged to the Hollandesa  and decided to stash it until all the fuss died down. Then a couple of weeks later, he heard about the offered reward and brought it out hoping to get his hands on those lovely 30000 dollars.
Foul play conjectures are unconvincing. If they were abducted, their kidnappers would probably have just taken their phones off them -and there would be no question of letting them 'phone emergency services. If they were murdered why would the killers go to the extent of getting rid of their remains using chemicals, but not get rid of the bag with all the things in it, most notably the camera and 'phones with all that can be deducted from what is on them? As for organ traffickers well those human scum-bags  have a pool of impoverished indigenes  at their disposal who are too inconsequential to be missed when they have been murdered; they don't need to pick on Western women about whom there will be a big outcry.  Picture 509? It never existed-technological items of whatever shape or form are always cocking things up. What about the taxi driver and those guys in the picture where they are supposedly swinmming with Kris and Lisanne ( though both womens parents are adamant that the girls in that picture are not theirs) who died mysteriously? They didn't die mysteriously. The taxi driver died in a road accident and everyone who knows these places knows that the people there drive like maniacs; road accidents are commonplace. As for the two guys they drowned. They were young  Latin males in a country where machismo is the thing and where snorting cocaine and drinking alcohol are everyday habits. They went swimming and drowned because they were out of it in some way; it happens all the time. As for cannibals and the paranormal being involved,  the exponents of these arguments can  discuss them  with their analysts........
comments.author: @kato119

comments.text:
What happened here was an accident. Kris and Lisanne wandered off the beaten path and got lost. Both tried to call emergency services to no avail. On April 8th, one week after they originally set off, both girls attempted to cross a monkey bridge at night and Kris fell and most likely died. Lisanne checked the head wound using her camera flash. Realising Kris was dead, Lisanne using paper set up an SOS and a mirror to try to grab attention from above to where Kris' body was. She took many photos at night of the sky to try to catch the attention of helicopters which at this point were looking for the girls and, using common sense, by now she would know there are people looking for them as they have not returned home for several days. Lisanne used two arrows made from twigs and plastic, one pointing to Kris' body, and the other across a monkey bridge, where she would be crossing to get help.

Lisanne's battery ran out on her phone as records show, and at this point, she was using Kris' phone which she could not access as she did not know the PIN. As bone fragments from both girls were found close together, Lisanne most likely also fell nearby and broke her foot and checked for a signal. Unable to go on, most likely she lay there on April 6 for five days to conserve her strength and did not try to use her phone until April 11th. She turned on the phone one last time and left it on for one hour hoping that someone would be able to call her. After an hour the phone was turned off to conserve battery and then passed away. Because she had only Kris' phone and did not know the PIN, Lisanne was unable to leave any messages to loved ones. Due to being in the forest, their bodies decomposed at an accelerated rate and got washed away/eaten by animals.

I cannot imagine what Lisanne was going through in her final days dying of starvation, thirst, and being totally alone.

comments.text:
I'm going to go ahead and throw my hat into the ring here.  I think that they became a little too confident after completing the hike, that they had been told wouldn't be easy, it's very possible that they took pictures of themselves at their destination (the end of the uphill trek), where there were signs visible that they shouldn't proceed without a guide.  Feeling a surge of adrenaline rushing through their systems, perhaps they decided to keep hiking past their original destination. After all, they were able to do it faster than expected, and may not have even realized that they were straying too far.  Whether or not it was arrogance, the adrenaline, or possibly even a spur of the moment longing to want their last adventure before returning to begin their work as teachers, they continued on into dangerous parts of the hike. 

Now, from here, any number of variables could come into play; maybe they were very unfortunate and they wandered to non-sturdy ground, due to the massive amount of rainfall that often occur in dense tropical forests, which may have caused one (or both) of the girls to have had a bad fall, possibly killing one of them upon impact, or, while less likely, may have caused severe blunt force trauma that either rendered one of their legs /feet completely useless, heck, maybe she landed against coarse rocks that clean cut the foot off. It'd be more likely that if such a thing were to happen, say if one of them either fell, or perhaps something, such as a rock formation shifting due to any number of things, such as landslides / flash flood(s) (you get the idea) occurred at some point, and they had to amputate the foot... There's just too many possible things that could go wrong, even if they didn't stray from the trail, as hiking (especially in foreign land) can be a very dangerous activity.  Perhaps one of the girls died, and the other, who was in shock, took a picture of her diseased companion out of fear from being accused of foul play, as well as trying to mark the area in which she died at - thinking that she would be able to find her own way out, not realizing that she may have been lost, going the wrong way, etc. which may be why she took so many pictures as well.  I don't like to theorize in this much detail, so I'll stick to the key points from here.  Just remember that this is purely theoretical, and only based off the information in this video. :)

Okay, as for the picture that was deleted and couldn't be restored - It's very possible, even likely, that the picture was in fact not intentionally deleted & wiped.  With the vast distance that it would've had to have traveled, it's fair to assume that the phone / camera could've had a corrupted file. Maybe due to all the photos already existing as well, there wasn't enough room for it to be stored in the first place, but devices like that will still try to create the appropriate format and file extension(s), followed by it being populated by the actual pixels of said picture.  If it lacks the room to fully populate the image, it would have already have pre-created a blank version of it, explaining the name / existence of the file, but it was overpopulated (past the maximum capacity to store the picture), it could easily have auto-deleted that blank formatted image file, which would lead anyone to believe that it was scrubbed cleaned after being deleted, when there wasn't anything there in the first place.  This also commonly occurs when the picture is taken and saved to it's NAND memory but is abruptly powered off.  When it's accessed again, it will either be corrupted, or just gone, making it seem as though the file in question did exist... ANYWAYS...

The rest is just impossible to speculate from the limited amount of details that are available, and honestly, I've already written a light novel with this comment in terms of length, lmao.  I think it was an accident, but regardless of what actually happened, thank God they're no longer suffering...  I pray that the family and friends of these girls are doing okay, as well.  It's really tragic, however, at the very least, there is closure in knowing that they are in fact dead, well, at least one of them has to be, and tbh, I do hope that they are both in a better place and not still out there, working for some drug cartel... I think we can all at least agree on that much.
comments.author: @BenSS3

comments.text: It is interesting how Kris was unsmiling and looked uneasy in her last photo at the river. Given the mood of their previous photos, they should both have been ideally standing on those rocks together smiling and taking photos together. The fact that this particular photo shows Kris alone at a distance on the river looking back with an uneasy expression on her face is a cause for concern. Even if she had instructed Lisanne to take a solo photo of her, she should have at least been smiling and posing because she was comfortable in her friend's company. This leads me to believe that they had already encountered their assailant(s) at this time. Perhaps it was the assailant behind the camera taking a photo of Kris for whatever reason hence her worried expression. The argument that they got lost holds no water simply because of the state some of their remains were found in and the detective is right, they would have left at least a message or something narrating what went wrong. Their bodies would also have been found intact because they would probably have died of starvation if they got lost in the jungle. The night photos are the biggest puzzle in my opinion. It makes no sense at all that they would suddenly decide to use the camera as a flash to illuminate the way after all those days. Even if that is the case, it doesn't explain the photos of the sky or kris' hair with hints of blood on it. I actually thought that that photo could have been Kris herself holding the camera behind her head to try and take a picture of the wound in order to assess the damage. If that is true, then it means that she must have been alone at this point and was probably taking pictures of the sky as a way to try and signal her position to Lisanne or potential search teams whom she would probably have expected to be on the lookout for them. The photos of the surrounding could then imply that something or someone was lurking nearby and she was trying desperately to see who/what it was. Based on the evidence, i know for a fact that it was murder. The only questions that remain unanswered are who did it, how they did it, why they did it and the location of the rest of the remains.

comments.text:
I am going to add a couple of comments, that I wrote in another video covering this case about a year back; that video, and a couple of others covering that case, have been taken down since then, very odd. Here are my thoughts from that video:

Everything points to foul play: from delayed investigations, to ignored evidence, culminating in rushed conclusions. 



Of special note, are the camera images supposedly used to communicate a message, and that "one deleted photo" which probably contained the face(s) of the perpetrator(s). In the latter case, the photo has been deleted professionally, to the point that you cannot recover it, someone used relatively sophisticated means to erase it; some have said that the members of the tribe that found the belongings deleted it for good, which is quite impossible (after all, tribes that live in the middle of nowhere aren't exactly high-tech savy), I repeat, you need advanced software to eliminate it, without damaging the rest of the photos. The other photos were probably taken and left intact, to fool people into thinking it was a freak wilderness expedition accident.



And most importantly, if the girls got lost on their own and actually wanted to communicate what happened to them... do you think they wouldn't have the brains to write a message on mud or soil, or with pieces of clothes, or with leaves, or rocks, or sticks, or anything, so that they could then take a picture of the message, to tell us exactly what had happened to them? Another possibility, is that they didn't have time to write such messages, because they were being chased by a person, considering that what remained of them has no sign of animal attacks.



Their disappearance was, undoubtedly, the act of a criminal group, with solid connections.

comments.text:
I've heard and read several versions of this story. Including a few Dutch documentaries and reports.
I believe your representation of the facts here is rather subjective. You have made assumptions, or have copied other peoples assumptions. You also implied that the Dutch research team has a different conclusion than the panama research team, and while they kept the investigation open for longer, they reached the same conclusion in the end.

You have left out a few crucial details about the case, including their attempts at making an sos message using toilet paper, including leaving a mirror to hopefully attract attention. Implying that they were trying to be found. And implying that they tried to stay put, waiting for rescue.

A few things to note: 
The search was relatively large for the country, but the area that had to be searched was a thick jungle. Also, the search was also not well structured. The area where the girls most likely were located, and stayed put in, was only touched on 2 weeks into the search. The bones were not as weirdly scattered as you make it out to be, as especially scavengers tend to spread remains over an area. The foot is an easy example of this. New forensic research that has only recently concluded has confirmed that there are no traces on the bones that imply human interaction with them. The "bleached" bone is more accurately described as most likely sunbleached. There is little more to it.
The missing photograph was deleted, but it is entirely possible that it was deleted by the girls using the camera. There is no evidence of it being done differently. Although it is entirely possible that the photo was deleted later by someone else.

It's a sad story. But everything points to girls getting lost in an immense jungle. Sadly losing their life to the wilderness.
comments.author: @PhantomCatMusic

comments.text:
I think their Diaries are a huge clue. 2 girls who wrote in their diaries every day would have definitely left a message if they're trying to call for Emergency every day starting April 1st. When Lisanne skipped a few days, her next entry she provided all 3 dates and said "Of course I'll fill you in." That was just a few days before she went missing. Of course they would leave a message. 
The Emergency calls could have easily been placed by the abductors handling their phone. Told to call it around the same time everyday and they didn't worry because they know there is no reception there. 1 of the calls makes a signal for 2 seconds, so what do they do next? They turn the phone off 36 seconds later. Now why would they turn the phone off now that they finally made a connection? Maybe they feared they would be traced.
Also the night photos are very creepy because that photo of Kris' hair seems to be on purpose. Why only 1 photo of hair, and why Kris' hair? Because we know it's Kris' hair and we don't question it. If it was Lisanne's hair we would assume it's her but so many people have brown hair that maybe it wouldn't be. They took a photo of Kris' hair to confirm it's the 2 missing girls, and imo the rest of the photos is a tease to investigators basically saying "You'll never find them, and you won't find this spot. Not in this big jungle.".
The photo of the red hair is in focus, it's not blurry. Which means they took their time taking that photo. Every strand of hair is in focus so they definitely were not moving. We only see her hair and nothing else. Also for being in the jungle for a week, that is the cleanest hair. No dirt, no grass, no leaves, her hair doesn't even appear wet. Yet we are supposed to believe Panama saying it's an accident and they fell off a monkey bridge into a river? That's not even possible when you look at the photos taken in a dry location. The orbs are probably from the mist from a river nearby, but they aren't in the river.
We've got a suspect that could be investigated but nobody bothered. I'm talking about the tour guide who is suspicious in every single way. Let me ask you something, how would you feel if your tour guide showed up at your house if you skipped a tour with him? Wouldn't you be creeped out? What if you skip an appointment at the barber shop, do you think it's normal for a barber to show up at your house, drop everything he's doing to come look for you? 
He's a tour guide, he's not that important. If you skip a tour with him it's not a big deal. He runs a coffee farm too, meaning he dropped everything and ran around town looking for 2 girls? Seems odd to me. He even entered the home they were staying at on April 2nd and stayed for about a half an hour. He literally went into their house. Maybe they had a hangover or slept-in did he ever think of that? Or did he worry that they spoke to others about meeting him so he wanted to protect himself by appearing concerned? Since he's the only proof we have of the April 2nd meeting at 8am. It's all according to him.
Also with a mystery this big, isn't it odd that it also has 1 of the biggest coincidences? Or maybe because it's not a coincidence. I mean how the tour guide who was supposed to meet these 2 girls, also finds their foot. I mean what a coincidence. Even the reporter he talked to about it felt the same way. He talks about finding the foot behind the tree, and the reporter's 1st response is "So it was invisible?" because how do you just so happen to spot a shoe behind a tree in dense jungle full of foliage. His response was "No well if we didn't happen to look behind that tree at that exact moment walking down the path, we never would have seen it." WOW well wasn't that convenient.
Also they conveniently find the backpack after the reward money was raised to $30,000??? There are way too many coincidences in this 1 mystery to be considered just a coincidence. That tour guide knows a lot more I believe. Even if he didn't harm the girls himself, I think he knows exactly what happened to them.
Then the tour guide gives Kris Kremers' parents their own tour to retrace their steps. The mom points to a path and the tour guide is like "NO, NO!" not there, anywhere but there. Here let me lead you down the path I choose, far away from any evidence. Then at the end of the tour, he casually takes out his camera, and snaps a photo of the grieving parents with the flash on, in  broad daylight. To be honest, when I saw that flash, I got an image of Kris' red hair from the night photo, with the flash on in focus.

comments.text: This case, not only sad like all of these are, definitely has its complexities. Scattered bones and dismemberment could have been from carrion animals, but bleached bones...According to forensic research conducted in the UK, it takes about six weeks during summer months in the UK for bones to begin to show signs of whitening and about nine weeks for bones to appear off-white. The UK isn't the jungles of Panama though, so if the bones were exposed to consistent UV rays, perhaps that process would be faster. This doesn't discredit animals from scattering the bones, but the backpack being clean and dry, their bras in the backpack, and an intentionally deleted photo that could only have been deleted by a computer rather than from the phone itself make this suspicious. Something else that doesn't sit well is that jungles are dense. You need a machete at the very least to make your way through if there isn't a path. If they were following a path and got into some difficult terrain, why not turn back? In the picture in which one of the girls looks anxious...the sun was still out. That's the most disturbing picture of all of them to me because that indicates a pivotal moment. Without a forensics team to investigate it, we'll likely never have the answers. As far as hiking alone, I'm not going to blame the victims. When there are two of you, you don't feel alone. And we don't know whether or not they were coerced to go further. My heart goes out to their loved ones.

comments.text:
I recommend Beast Runners YouTube, he documents his mountain SAR volunteer work and he finds people all the time. The number one thing that happens is they get lost, injured, and mistakenly think following a river will lead them back to civilization. Pretty much his first thing is to follow the trails and then follow the creeks or rivers near them, and he finds a shocking amount of people.
That conceivably matches this case. They could have hiked beyond the divide, one (probably Kris) fell and was injured, and with limited mobility, they decided to follow the Changuinola river or one of its tributaries, mistakenly thinking it would lead back to Bocquette. They eventually die of exposure or injury along the riverside and that explains the dispersal of their remains.
On the other hand, there are multiple people on YouTube who've hiked the Mirador del Pianista, even beyond the summit, and the consensus seems to be that no one can figure out how they'd get lost in the first place. There are also multiple farms along the riverside. It's remote but there are farmers there and those trails are used by locals (even reviews of the hike mention meeting several friendly local farmers along these trails).
So I don't know either.
There's also the theory that both scenarios happened -- they legitimately got lost/injured, but the wrong people found them.
comments.author: @xbmarx

comments.text: when i was 14 years old i traveled to panama with a summer study abroad program. the year was 2014 & the other members (notably all girls, including our two guides/teachers) and i arrived in boquete to stay for a few days, planning on white water rafting, rock climbing, & hiking. on our first or second night in boquete, we stopped at a casual restaurant for dinner. shortly after sitting down, an older american man positioned himself at the end of our table & attempted to strike a conversation with us. there was something off putting about him & we all acted standoffish towards him, signaling that we had no interest in entertaining a conversation. he didnâ€™t really take the hint & continued to ask us questions about who we were, how long weâ€™re here for, etc. perhaps finally acknowledging our discomfort, he signaled that he was on his way out but before departing, he told us that we were â€œvery braveâ€ for coming here. the word choice & tone was odd, prompting one of our girls to bluntly ask him why. he didnâ€™t provide a clear answer. he just grinned, muttered a few unintelligible words, and walked out. it was a somewhat insignificant interaction, and even though there was something unsettling about him, i just chalked up his insistence to talk with us to loneliness or boredom. but even as this experience was topically insignificant, itâ€™s always stuck with me for some reason. i always wondered what exactly he meant by â€œvery braveâ€. but learning about kris & lisanneâ€™s disappearance happening only weeks before in the same area, i now understand a little better what he meant by that. for my own peace of mind, iâ€™ll think of that man as imparting us with a warning, and not a threat.

comments.text:
They didnt go beyond EL Mirador on the Carabian side of the continental divide. They returned to the summit.   
There are 3 explanations to this crime:  
1) Nina Von RÃ¶nne claims it was Feliciano Gonzales, who killed the girls in a fit of rage, for rejecting his advances. They had rejected his suggestion of staying with him on his Coffee farm. The did not book a hike with him on the second of april 2014. That was FelicianoÂ´s excuse to go their room and stay in it for 30 minutes with Miriam G. What is he dooing in their room for 30 minutes? 
2) It was the deeply criminal  Los 5 gang: Henry Elizar Gonzales, the son of tour guide Feliciano Gonzales, met the girls with Jorge Murgas (dead) and Osman Velezuals (dead), at the pharmacy on the day of their disapperance according to the pharmacists son, Jorge Rivera Miranda (dead). Four out of Los 5 gang are dead. Still alive is Henry Elizar Gonzales. 
3) It was Edwin Aguierre and Vega Moises - both deeply involved with the Mafia and an Organ Harvesting Kartell in Costa Rica. 
The official version is they got lost in the jungle. But a witness has come forward and claimed, that the girls returned from the hike, and got into a car. The car belonged to Feliciano Gonzales but it was driven by his son, Henry Elizar Gonzales. They drove to the Caldera Springs and swam with Jorge Murgas and Osman Velezuales. It was Henry Elizar Gonzales that took the picture of the girls with Jorge and Osman. The deleted picture 509, is from the Caldera Springs.

The girls were kept in a cave guarded by Jorge Murgas, while Henry Elizar Gonzales went to the Sabron resturent, where he met with Edwin Aguirre and Vega Moises. comments.text:
I have grown up next to the Alps, you can see the Monviso from my balcony, my house is at 580 metres elevation and there's a woodland just behind, with a lot of wild boars and licensed hunters and poachers in the national park area. 

I live one hour and half (well a bit more if you drive safely) from the tallest peak in Europe, the Most Blanc, my first hike there was the summer before I started elementary school, I was six years old. We had just came back from Egypt, where we had trekked in the desert a lot and before school started, my dad took me hiking and camping at high elevation on the Mont Blanc. He's a former servicemen as are many people from my area, from the Alpine Regiment, the mountaineer military regiment, they do their basic at altitude, they are the best trackers, hikers, rock climbers with specific military training for the Alps. 

I have hiked in both Sarawak and Sabah in Borneo, I have climbed Mount Kinabalu, I have trekked in on 3 different holidays in Malaysia, I also have travelled and hiked in Indonesia, in Vietnam, twice in Thailand. 

I can tell you that. I once got lost in the woods behind my house, a place that I know like the back of my hand, a wooded area, where it gets dark quickly as that side of the hill is covered by another hill, so the sun goes down early, add to that thick vegetation. 

I was lost for five hours. FIVE hours and at no point I was more than 800 metres away from my house, I honestly thought I would not make it out alive. Luckily, I had a map, compass, a swiss army knife, an opinel knife, a hatchet, a canteen with water and one canteen with a guarana, vitamins and protein, I had a waterproof torch in my trousers, a bigger torch in my backpack, I had protein bars in my trouser pockets and other highly nutritional bars. 

I also had a spare smartphone in my bag, attached to a USB battery with four ports, fully charged. Yet both my phones had malfunctioning GPS. 

I went off trail for no more than 50 paces, jumped over a small stream, stopped to have a snack, then when I got up, I could not trace my way back to the trail. Walked for hours to the point of exhaustion. Luckily the nutrition and caffeine drink I had kept me going. 

I also made a mistake in navigating with map and compass. 


As I said I'm from the Alps, I have been trekking, hiking and camping at altitude since I'm six years old, including on the Mont Blanc at the highest level you can reach before rockclimbing, where the trees gave way to rocks. Harsh terrain. First with folks, then with my friends from the Alpine Regiment, then alone. 

Let me tell you, if the Alps can kill you in one night due to temperature drops, falls into ravines, etc.. and you can get lost and not find your trail even if you walked off it for 25 paces to relieve yourself, from my experience in Borneo and other places in Malaysia and other Southeast Asian countries, you can go off trail for five paces, stop to take a dump, and not be able to trace back where you came from. 

It is that easy. It really that easy, listen to some of the military guys here and what they say. 

Forests and jungles are unforgiving as are the mountains. Even experienced, by my standards, so veterans of the Alpine Regiment, locals who have grown up on the Alps and have twenty years of weekly hikes, ten day hikes, high elevation camping, even they succumb to the elements, either hypothermia, paradoxical undressing or simple falls. 

I never venture out without a backpack with a sleeping bag in it. 
In my pockets I carry, attached to small ropes tied to my trousers:
-One torch
-One swiss army general utility knife
-An opinel
-A compass
-proten bars

In my backpack I also carry a spare torch, a hatchet, a spare map, another compass, an extra smartphone attached to a USB battery. Plus food rations and two canteens. 

I always wear trekking shoes, never wear shorts (NEVER), always have trousers that can withstand rain and/or snow, depending on season or how how far up I'm going, always have a coat that will be good for both rain and snow and extra warm clothing. 

I read so many posts made in the comment section by Youtube "experts", who would probably struggle to find a way out of their mom's basement, making claims like "you cannot get lost on that trail"...in one case one guy was arguing against a man who had underwent jungle training in Panama in the military (down in this very comment section), can you imagine the arrogance of some basement dweller saying to this man, "no you're wrong you cannot get lost there I've watched a docu on it". How could you possibly be so arrogant to disagree with somebody who's been there and done that in the military while you ahve never been in that terrain or a similar terrain. 

WHAT? You can get lost on ANY trail, even in places you are familiar with, let alone a tropical jungle you have no knowledge of. They had only been in country for one bloody week, that's not even enough time to acclimatize.

Ten paces off trail to pee, you are about to pee against a tree when you see movement, thinking snake or spider you move away and turn, now if you retrace back your steps, you will NOT end up back in the trail as you have turned and moved. If you had stayed with your back to the trail, you could turn around and walk back. However just moving about can mean getting lost. 

Some people here going for the murder theory underestimate how bloody intense and thick a jungle is, take the woods and multiply by many measures, louder sounds, a background of wildlife noise that can be overwhelming, heat, humidity, slippery rocks, the most DENSE vegetation you can imagine. 

As I said my first two treks were at six years of age in the summer of 1990, right before starting elementary school, trekking in the desert in Egypt, followed by hiking and camping at high altitude on the Mont Blanc, on the Alps. 

I'm 37, I have decades of experience under my belt and I could easily be swallowed up by the woods that surround my house. 

Please never underestimate the outdoors.

comments.text: The case is clear cut.  Two girls who were ill-prepared for the journey they put themselves on, got lost in the jungle.  Because they were ill-prepared, they likely succumbed to the mental rigors that dehydration and likely hypothermia they would have suffered at night would have taken on them.  The one fell at some point, hence the broken foot in the boot, this wouldn't have happened at the time of the fall but the girls were out in the jungle for at least 12 weeks til they were found.  When Lisanne fell, Kris after time knew she was the one stuck to go get help either before or after Lisanne was dead.  The pictures at night are to mark where Lisanne was left so that if Kris found help, they could go rescue or recover Lisanne.  Studies show bones become fully bleached after 9 weeks.  Animals would have scavenged on whatever was available of their bodies for food.  They were following a river, because usually following a river downstream leads to civilization, the bag went into the water at some point and went downriver, if it ended up on the shore, it could have been there for days in the pounding sun to dry.  All of this is a tragic accident and a lesson that when the battle is human vs nature, nature will always win.  But let's suppose you want the foul play theory.  A. would the girls have been allowed to try to call for help repeatedly over the course of several days?  B. would the backpack ever have been found?  Seriously, there was like 80 dollars in there, in an impoverished area.  It wouldn't have been taken?  Come on.  C.  Would the phones ever have been found with abductors knowing that incriminating evidence could have been on the camera.  But sure, lets say they just deleted the one photograph instead.  D. Would the bodies have even ever been found?  Logically, an abduction murder makes no sense given the facts of the case.

comments.text:
I do believe the girls got lost and probably spent a few hours trying to find their way back before they realized they couldn't and started making the emergency calls. They most likely switched their phones off after the calls failed to go through to conserve battery power and decided on calling emergency services one time a day. Sadly, Kris may have met her end first leaving Lisanne alone which could explain the wrong pin being entered on Kris' phone. The night time pictures may have been markers for anyone who found the camera. 

I think there was shady stuff going on after they were already dead. The Government was probably covering things up to protect their tourist industry. But I don't see much evidence to imply that they were abducted. The tour guide going into their room for  30 minutes alone while the girls were missing was suspicious . But the pictures that were released don't really indicate someone was following them and their calls also don't indicate they were frantically trying to get ahold of help because they were in immediate danger from someone. As for the deleted picture, I actually believe it was the police that deleted the photo to hide something, again to protect their tourism. This is a sad case overall and I mourn for these girls and their families.

comments.text:
So, a couple things to note.  Scavenger animals could easily have caused the vast distances of the bones.  It could also explain the bleaching, if the bone was picked clean and left in the sun long enough.  Without more details, that's hard to say.  Am I saying with confidence that this was the case, no.   But, it is a reason they could have concluded an accidental death.  Regarding the bag, that's a tough one.  Assuming the lady that found it was telling the truth, and did not have it longer, it seems someone would have placed it where it was found.  But, they could have found it in a much different way, and only got scared when investigations were happening in their village and just didn't want to be a part of it.  Let's face it, people lie.  

All in all, it's an interesting case.  Why the picture of the back of the head?  Was it to document what happened, was the flashing being used as a light because they heard something in the wilderness that scared them?  That seems more probable to me.  But, why was a photo deleted?  Very strange and so little information to go on.  These types of cases are just difficult in general.  And since it doesn't seem that a full body was ever found, it's even more difficult to answer.  I am curious why more caves  or outcroppings of rocks were not checked in the jungles near the areas where items were found.  It's clear in the photo that they were in some sort of cave or under some sort of outcropping.  It would be interesting to retrace their steps based on their photos as best as possible.
comments.author: @SamMaeder

I don't think it would be some sort of animal attack since it did state that the cuts were mostly clean cuts and not one that looks like it could be from an animal plus no animal could just cut them up and scatter their body parts and very far apart at that so it hints that it's likely done by more than 1 or 2 people. comments.text:
In the disappearance of these two Dutch girls, there are two situations that I don't understand and I believe that need a more careful analysis:
1-If in the first two calls to the Dutch emergency number, they were already under the control of kidnappers, why didn't the criminals take the phones, the camera and all their belongings?

This doesn't make any sense! No offenders with murderous or sexual intentions would risk being photographed by their victims, or even risk the girls calling the police or leaving a message recorded on their cell phones for when they are found by the authorities.

2- Why don't you have any attempt to call 911 during the night?

What would be the worst moment for two girls from an urban environment, lost in the middle of a tropical jungle?
Do you agree with me that this worst moment would be to spend the night in the forest?! Exhausted, cold, with animals moving on the ground, animal movement in the dark forest, a plague of insects, rain spray, hunger, thirst and darkness everywhere. This would undoubtedly be the time when they would most try to connect to an emergency number, but they didn't.

Trying to explain these two situations, the best way to harmonize was as follows:
Lisanne and Kris decided on their own, to continue the trail past the viewpoint, when they realized they couldn't make it back before nightfall, or because they really got lost and disoriented, they decided to make the first two calls in the late afternoon of April 1st. . Without success, they must surely have screamed for help. They were certainly answered and rescued by someone who heard them both scream, or someone who somehow passed them on the trail. This would explain why the girls did not attempt to call an emergency number during the night, that is, they felt safe to be accompanied by someone they believed to be trustworthy and well intentioned.
After that, they certainly went with that someone, to some nearby property, where they continued to be deceived by lies that reassured them, but that at dawn and after a night's sleep, they always tried to make another emergency call, until the cell phone battery has discharged.
It was at that moment that this someone realized that they were totally incommunicado and certainly decided to attack and take their belongings that were all inside the backpack.
From then on, all the evil that befell the girls began.

In my opinion, between the moment the last cell phone ran out of charge and the dawn of the 8th, Kris Kremers was killed, so in the photos taken on the 8th, only the hair of a lifeless body of Kris appears, trying to simulate a disappearance, with them lost in the night trying to signal their position in the woods and kris dead in Lisanne's arms (who doesn't appear in the photos) as it's the killer planting false evidence, not Lisanne!

As the pieces of Lisanne Froon's skin were found in mid-June, in an initial state of decomposition, this shows that Lisanne was killed in early June and was under the control of this someone who killed her, for about 60 days. She was the last to die.

Note 1: Seeing the holes in Kris' Jeans, it shows that her dead body was dragged a short distance, where it was thrown. That is, this may indicate that the place where Kris and Lisanne were killed and the bodies were subjected to a chemical treatment for dismemberment and then concealment, are very close to each other, and may be in the vicinity of this property where they felt "safe" .

Note 2: The photo of Kris' hair at night, may not have been photographed in the forest, but in a closed and dark environment.

Note 3: Kris' boot found, was it clean and without any remains inside? No animal in the forest, would be interested in carrying a leather boot in her mouth! It's not food! That's how the animals would see this boot, any object, they would have smelled it and gone. That boot was taken to the forest by the killer.

Note 4: The police know of more evidence, maybe even the photo that was deleted. At the very least, they want to make some strategic use.

Conclusion: Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon, were held captive in an environment they thought was safe, were killed, stripped naked, with the bodies being dismembered by some chemical process as yet unknown. Some dismembered parts, along with the girls' boots, clothes and backpack with all the girls' belongings, were deliberately abandoned along the straight-line trail to create false leads and simulate that the girls died of hunger and thirst after getting lost in the deep in the forest.

The death of these innocent girls touched me a lot! This is my small contribution to unravel their deaths and thus lead to a punishment, the possible murderer and the possible collaborators.

Fortaleza-CE, Brazil.

I very much hope that Jesus Christ will comfort Kris and Lisanne's parents.

comments.text:
My best guess is that foul play was involved, but I think it is also possible that Kreemer died of natural causes. 

What makes me question that are two things - The photo of Kreemer's head, and her bleached bones. It can take 6 - 9 weeks, depending on varying factors, for bones to bleach naturally. 

I think it is possible the girls got lost, panicked, and Kreemer slipped and hit her head while searching for a high point to gain signal and call for help. 

As for what happened to Froon.. That I don't know. I doubt she would have wanted to leave her injured friend, but once Kreemer passed, she would have had to move to avoid Kreemer's remains attracting predators to her location. I think this would also explain why Kreemer's remains were so scattered - Possibly Vultures? 

From this point, Froon could have also died of natural causes - But I think it is more likely she was killed, and their backpack was taken. 

I think the key to their deaths lies with their backpack. They should have questioned the lady who found it more thoroughly - She may have known more than she was letting on, or could even have been responsible for Froon's death. 

Such a tragic story. At least we can hope they didn't die alone - They had each other in their final moments. May they rest eternally.

comments.text: My instinct (form a hiker's perspective): They reached the summit. Took their pictures and prepared to start the same path down, when a man appeared and chatted them up. He said he could show them the waterfall. They agreed. They were poorly prepared even for the hike they had planned - only one bottle of water and no food. So they would not of their own accord have decided to continue. So this person was quite convincing. I think he convinced only one of the girls and the other went along. The guide took them to the waterfall and looked on while these uninhibited Dutch girls took off their clothes and bathed under the waterfall. Hence the bras packed neatly in the backpack. Then he did not take them back, but deeper into the jungle. It would have dawned on them very slowly that they had made a terrible mistake. But they stayed alive by pretending to still trust him and going along with his games and pretending nothing was wrong. Surreptitiously they tried to make emergency calls. The brute dismembered them (probably carried a panga/machete with him, which at first did not disturb them) and spread their remains around the jungle. Of course he did not want to be caught with their backpack, so he put it down somewhere to be found, hoping that would end the search parties.

comments.text:
It actually sounds more like a ritual killing as there are still factions that practice indigenous magick involving cannibalism. The bleaching of the bones is often done when creating ritual objects out of them. A femur staff. A rib fetish. Incomplete remains and the scattering would also point to the remains having been scavenged after the required items were gathered, leaving the rest for wild life. There is a black market for human bones and body parts for use in ritual. Itâ€™s the most logical explanation, if not the strangest explanation. People practice Santeria and those scratched in to Palo would have the most use for it. The fact they were both white and blonde would add another reason for them being chosen as Caucasian bones would have higher value that indigenous ones. 

It might sound crazy, because it is, but human sacrifice is very much alive in the southern americas, amongst many gang factions and magickal practitioners.

comments.text:
I'm sceptical of the murder theories, although they're understandable, given past crimes involving young women hikers in foreign countries. I have myself been seriously lost in the woods twice, and once guided out a young woman lost in the woods at night while I was camping just off the Appalachian trail. Each time it was dramatic how fast disorientation and panic set in - it's the panic-fear that makes one automatically do the opposite of what one should do. It's not like your car's GPS stops working on a road trip. It's more like falling off a cruise ship and watching it disappear over the horizon. I can only infer that in the most serious cases, especially after days of food deprivation and chronic anxiety and stress, disorientation could become so severe that the two inexperienced girls in the Panama case would begin acting almost pathologically confused, while desperate hope may have led them to forego goodbye messages for the sake of attempts to reach local rescue until the batteries in their phones went dead and it was too late.

I've watched a couple of the better pieced-together videos and I found myself getting sceptical of the murder theories when I saw too much bias in that direction. For example, some of the "happy" photos early on in their hike were slightly distorted or the clouds seemed mis-timed from one snap to the next or the one girl was supposedly a little depressed or anxious looking, and to me all that seemed overly subjective and irrelevant to any criminal activity. The idea of any killers allowing their victims to keep taking photos is ridiculous, not just because it creates possible evidence but because abduction and murder (rape also) is about having complete power and control over someone.

Why would a killer and not the girls turn the phones on and off? Only the girls had any reason to do that repeatedly, and if they had the chance to do so around an abductor, they also would have had the chance to escape. The backpack could have been misplaced by the girls in their disoriented state until a villager found and took it, then returned it, dry, to the same (or a different) spot once they got wind of rescue efforts for the owner of the backpack and realized it might implicate them in more than just â€œfinders, keepers.â€

As for the photos in the camera, how would taking dozens of photos of the sky at night serve to mislead police? And the height-distorted photo of Lisanne? Digital photos occasionally are goofy like that (I have a rear-view pic of my motorcycle where the panniers look like two different sizes). The clouds at the trail overlook completely mismatching in photos taken seconds apart? Weird, but how does that suggest foul play, when the girls are posing normally? The deleted photo? A tech-savvy killer would only take the batteries out of the phones and throw everything in the river or bury it all, making deleting photos unnecessary and also increasing the mystery to the killerâ€™s advantage. Anyways, why disguise a murder as an accident, when both possibilities (murder or losing their way) are going to be speculated about regardless? I can certainly see the girls using the camera flashes to attempt signalling toward airplane sounds and checking for hazards in their path (note the one photo of a dangerous drop down a rock). Furthermore, why would a killer force-march two victims miles through a jungle, only to kill them in the middle of nowhere? That makes no sense - killers aren't lazy, but what advantage would there be to the killer? 

I think these girls just got hopelessly lost, and that leads me back to my own experiences of being lost in the woods - the more you try to guess your way out in a panicked and confused state of mind, the more lost you get. To me, the most important thing about this tragedy isn't how the girls died, but the decisions they made leading up to their disappearance. They'd worked hard as waitresses in the Netherlands to save for the trip and they were young, idealistic and eager, so it's understandable they'd be adventurous. But they'd already reached their goal of living in that small tropical town in Panama and they hadn't even seriously explored the town itself yet. They had a guided hike scheduled for the next day. What was the hurry to get into the jungle? Going to extremes is always a dangerous thing, and getting too adventurous too soon was going to an extreme. I think the girls were their own killers.

This story always disgusts me. Especially the photo of Kris... as I feel very certain that they weren't alive when the photos were taken. It seems like someone was playing with the camera, albeit, in the dark, and in the jungle. Someone fascinated by her hair color. They're very freaky photos if you look carefully, think of the person taking them, in the dark, and in the rain. I cannot imagine what these girls went through, it's truly heartbreaking. 
At the end of the day, not enough was done, and prosecutor Betzaida Pitti only cared to sweep this under the rug, which is disgusting. People should be reminded that Panama's government did NOT uphold their responsibility to properly or thoroughly investigate these deaths in order to protect visitors and locals alike. Also, I find it pretty disturbing that Ms. Pitti was one of the authors of the book "Lost in the Jungle", which whitewashed their mistakes. It ends by blaming the girls, talking about what they were wearing and such...
Very unfortunately, I don't think this case will ever be solved. They even messed up Kris's name on the memorial plaque... smh

For anyone looking for more info on this case. I came across some very detailed articles, one on the website imperfect plan, written by Chrisâ€¦ Idk, he didn't leave a last name, but whoever put that together really went all the way in. They should have been leading the investigation!! There is also a blog written by Scarlet R. on Koude Kaas, titled "The missing Dutch girls in Panama, Part 2 - the swimming photo". Where she puts together a whole lot of information about some of the possible causes surrounding the swimming photos, mysterious deaths, etc. Anyway, be safe out there, people, and be kind to one another!

comments.text:
You are just repeating what other youtubers have got wrong and their own assumptions, a pretty good investigation was made many years ago by someone who was actually there and had access to all the photos, and talked directly to the police and other private investigators and they came to the conclusion that at one point in the row they took a wrong turn, they got lost, crossed a bridge notorious for being dangerous(locals don't even use it) and got deep into the jungle far away from their route. apparently Kris fell and injured her head, they tried to call for help with Lisanne and Kris phone but they had no signal, the next day Lisanne made several attempts with her phone but couldn't connect, there are pictures of Kris head several actually where you can see blood, apparently Lisanne was trying to see Kris injury in the night with the flash of the camera. Lisanne walked back during the day to try to find signal but came back to Kris during the night. Lisanne phone ran out of battery and she was using Kris phone, she takes a picture of Kris laying on the ground and starts walking back leaving markers, taking photos of them and probably using the flash to walk at night, she arrives to the bridge that she had crossed before but it's been 11 days now and she is weak and falls, some of her belongings are found under the bridge, her remains and other belongings are found several days later downstream from the place she fell. remains of Kris are also found scattered around.

So ther was no foul play, no murder, it just looks like they got lost, Kris got injured and Lissane didn't want to leave her friend alone, apparently she didn't decide to walk further back the road until Kris died or was completely unconscious and even then she took photos of where she was to find her way back to her, sadly she fell too. Must have been horrible to be lost in the jungle alone and with your friend dying next to you.
